awd_titl_txt: Computational Modeling of Protein Degradation by Biological Nanomachines
awd_abstract_narration:
Cell survival is critically dependent on tightly regulated protein degradation mechanisms. Biological nanomachines that mediate protein degradation use repetitive mechanical forces to unfold, translocate (move), and destroy excess or defective proteins. Understanding these mechanisms is of central importance for deciphering the details of essential cellular processes. This project will use computer simulations at multiple scales to elucidate 1) the dependence of protein unfolding and translocation actions on force directionality and 2) the nature of collaboration between components of the biological machines involved in the degradation process. The knowledge gained through this project will advance understanding of the relationship between structure and function in these biological nanomachines and will reveal fundamental principles of protein unfolding and translocation. This project integrates the training of undergraduate and graduate students in computational biophysical chemistry through addressing advanced scientific problems. Increased participation of underrepresented minorities in computational sciences will be promoted through educational and mentoring efforts. This goal will be achieved through the collaboration between the University of Cincinnati and Central State University (CSU), a Historically Black College and University, and will combine outreach activities at CSU with research experience opportunities for underrepresented minorities in the PI's laboratory. The results of this project will be disseminated widely to the general public by the PI, graduate and undergraduate students through publications, conference presentations, the web, and seminars at CSU.

This project will elucidate the effect of mechanical anisotropy on unfolding and translocation of multidomain substrate proteins by bacterial Clp ATPases, which are members of the AAA+ superfamily of biological nanomachines.  Multiscale models will be developed to probe nanomachine-mediated threading of multidomain constructs of substrate proteins with diverse topology and mechanical stability along specific directions. Computer simulations using these models will be complemented by experiments conducted by collaborators to pinpoint remodeling pathways in restricted and unrestricted geometries. The project will also elucidate the collaboration between Clp ATPase and peptidase components for protein threading. Computer simulations of atomistic and coarse-grained models will be performed to obtain a detailed understanding of allosteric conformational transitions of the peptidase and their role in substrate translocation. These simulations, in conjunction with experimental studies conducted by collaborators, will establish the residue-level interactions that underlie component specialization in these biological machines.

por.por_cntn:
AAA+ (ATPases associated with diverse cellular activities) nanomachines utilize mechanical forces to assist essential cellular processes such as DNA replication, protein degradation, or disassembly of toxic protein aggregates. The recognizable feature of these machine is a hexameric structure enclosing a narrow central channel. Catalytic activity is provided by one or two conserved nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs), or AAA domains, that power large-scale conformational transitions of individual subunits through ATP hydrolysis. The hallmark mechanical action of the AAA+ machines involves gripping and applying force onto the substrate protein (SP) through a set of flexible loops, one in each NBD, that protrude into the central channel and undergo repetitive axial motions in nonconcerted allosteric cycles. Our coarse-grained and atomistic simulations of Clp-mediated remodeling of single and tandem SPs comprising fusion I27 domains probed direction-dependent unfolding mechanisms. An important outcome was to obtain an understanding of the effect of the plasticity of Clp ATPase oligomer on SP unfolding. Our simulations revealed that the open pore configuration of the Clp ATPase favors unfolding of I27 along a softer mechanical direction through an unzipping mechanism and that the closed pore configurations favor unfolding along a stronger mechanical direction through a shearing mechanism. An additional important outcome was to elucidate the role of diffusion on these mechanisms. To this end, we developed simulation models that represent the Clp-SP system in atomistic detail and probe the repetitive mechanical pulling of the SP applied by the Clp ATPase. We found that the presence of multiple folded domains in a tandem SP strongly affects the rotational diffusion of folded domains through a crowding effect and results in branching of unfolding pathways due to sampling of multiple SP orientations. In additional simulations, we compared and contrasted these mechanisms with those in a restrained geometry that mimics the single-molecule force spectroscopy setup. In accord with the experimental results, we found single unfolding pathways consistent with the mechanical interface along the N-C direction and weak effects due to the presence of multiple folded domains. An important outcome of this project was to elucidate the effect of sequence directionality on the protein degradation process. Distinct unfolding requirements associated with application of the pulling force at each protein terminal are proposed to act as selectivity filters in directional degradation. We probed these unfolding and translocation mechanisms by performing coarse-grained simulations of the green fluorescent protein substrate threading in the N-C or C-N directions mediated by the ATPase motor of the 26S proteasome. We found that asymmetric unfolding requirements in N- and C-terminal pulling arise from the interplay of mechanical stability near the terminal engaged first by the proteasome, rotational flexibility of the partially unfolded fragment and translocation. Strikingly, our simulations indicated that intermittent application of force that mimics variable gripping of the substrate protein by the AAA+ motor results in slower unfolding kinetics when force is applied at the softer mechanical interface at the N-terminal. On the basis of these results, we proposed that the combination of kinetic, thermodynamic and mechanical requirements control directional degradation by the proteasome. This project involved tight integration of research and educational goals by providing research opportunities for underrepresented minority students and training of undergraduate and graduate students in computational biophysics. An important outcome was the increased participation of underrepresented minority students in computational sciences through our collaboration with Historically Black College and Universities. Our group provided mentoring to three female undergraduate students from Central State University and one female student from Virginia State University, who were trained in computational biophysics, participated in research on Clp ATPases and received mentoring in scientific communication and preparing for graduate studies. Students gave presentations at the University of Cincinnati (UC), presented at national meetings, and co-authored publications from our group. One student received an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship and started her graduate studies. Students also received training in big data science approaches in chemistry. An additional important outcome was to provide highly skilled knowledge in computational biophysics for undergraduate and graduate students. Nine UC undergraduate students (including four female students) performed research in our lab and eight completed capstone projects, and presented posters at UC All-University undergraduate sessions. One female undergraduate student co-authored a publication from our group and one started graduate studies. In addition, I provided mentoring to several recent group members who started postdoctoral or tenure-track positions.
